item.title: First episode
item.description: My Description

item.title: TITLE
item.description: DESCRIPTION

item.title: Making Germany Hate Again
item.description: Joshua Hammer InLook Away, Jacob Kushner draws a disturbing portrait of the white supremacist subculture that took hold across eastern Germany in the 1990s and now is making gains at the ballot box.

item.title: The Occupation of Looking
item.description: Susan Tallman The discipline of art history today is far more inclusive, more cognizant of social history, and less prone to normative aesthetic judgments—changes Svetlana Alpers helped bring about.

item.title: The Darkroom of Propaganda
item.description: Andrew O’Hagan “It now shows in the lower depths of the Internet as well as on talk radio shows and a hundred perfidious podcasts, where the sleep of reason becomes a populist mania, and hostility a kind of sport.”

item.title: Trump at the Supreme Court
item.description: Linda Greenhouse “The amateurish nature of many of the first Trump administration’s encounters with the Supreme Court is highly likely to be replaced by a more disciplined and strategic approach.”

item.title: Antisystemic Times
item.description: Ben Tarnoff “Large numbers of Americans have come to believe that their body politic is severely diseased. In Trump, they have found a man ruthless enough to inflict the remedy.”

item.title: On Abortion Rights
item.description: Christine Henneberg “I, like physicians in Texas, Idaho, and elsewhere, will be forced to turn patients away—not for medical reasons, not because I am not trained to help them, but because of moral decrees handed down by politicians.”

item.title: The Rise of Authoritarianism
item.description: Aryeh Neier The triumph of Trump and Trumpism in the United States will add legitimacy to the rule of autocrats all over the world.

item.title: The Task of the Journalist
item.description: Wesley Lowery “Our highest calling is not short-term persuasion or immediate influence but diligent documentation.”

item.title: Nemesis
item.description: Susan Neiman “Will workers be served by a president who openly praises union-busters? Of course not, but Trump’s promise was to be their retribution, not to solve their problems.”

item.title: Words Without Consequences
item.description: Michael Hofmann “How can one not see through something so threadbare, so self-serving, so randomly and contemptuously thrown out by the self-adoring crooner?”

item.title: The Midnight World
item.description: Michael Chabon Glenn Fleishman’s history of the comic strip as a technological artifact vividly restores the world of newspaper printing—gamboge, Zip-A-Tone, flongs, and all.

item.title: Hallelujah!
item.description: Jenny Uglow In his bookEvery Valley, Charles King explains the enduring appeal of Handel’sMessiahsince its premiere in Dublin nearly three hundred years ago.

item.title: The Cuttlefish’s Play
item.description: Regina Marler Richard Powers’sPlaygrounddoes for oceans what his 2018 novelThe Overstorydid for trees: it implores us to open ourselves to the ingenuity of life beyond the human.

item.title: Making Germany Hate Again
item.description: Joshua Hammer InLook Away, Jacob Kushner draws a disturbing portrait of the white supremacist subculture that took hold across eastern Germany in the 1990s and now is making gains at the ballot box.

item.title: Intimate Theatricality
item.description: Carolina A. Miranda Meticulously installed domestic spaces set the tone for Mickalene Thomas’s current exhibition, which features the work for which she is best known: sumptuous portraits of Black women in repose—the artist’s mother, lovers, and friends.

item.title: The Barrens
item.description: Karen Solie a poem

item.title: Lebanon’s Year of Living Ambiguously
item.description: Charles Glass After the Hezbollah leader Sheikh Hassan Nasrallah decided to draw Lebanon into the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, tit-for-tat bombings along the border with Israel overshadowed the country’s political and economic plight.

item.title: The Shoals of Prose
item.description: Ange Mlinko Recent books of prose by two of our best poets suggest the importance of criticism to the development of a poet’s work.

item.title: Reports from the Slaughterhouse
item.description: Martha C. Nussbaum A century after Upton Sinclair exposed the inhumane and unhygienic conditions of Chicago’s stockyards, life for animals in America’s factory farms and slaughterhouses is still gruesome.

item.title: The Architect Who Unified America
item.description: Martin Filler H. H. Richardson invented a practical, adaptable style for American civic architecture that was used for decades after his death.

item.title: You Only Live Twice
item.description: Alexander Leggatt Shakespeare’s characters often navigate the dangerous possibility of a second chance.

item.title: Gender-Affirming Care & the Courts
item.description: David Cole The Supreme Court will rule this term on whether a Tennessee law denying minors treatment for gender dysphoria discriminates on the basis of sex.

item.title: A Very Quiet Symphony
item.description: Joanna Biggs Eliza Barry Callahan’sThe Hearing Testseems to be about a temporary loss of hearing but is actually one woman’s rehearsal for the losses that come, unbidden, for us all.

item.title: Snow Elegy
item.description: Ishion Hutchinson a poem

item.title: Israel’s Revenge: An Interview with Rashid Khalidi
item.description: Mark O’Connell, an interview withRashid Khalidi The scholar of Palestinian history talks about what has and has not surprised him about the world‘s response to Israel‘s assault on Gaza.

enclosure.url: https://the-ted.github.io/podcast/mp3/Israel’s Revenge: An Interview with Rashid Khalidi.mp3

item.title: Look Who’s Talking
item.description: Ian Tattersall When did our first linguistic ancestor emerge, and how did the transition from a nonlinguistic to a linguistic state take place?

item.title: As You Like It
item.description: Gabriel Winslow-Yost Sam Barlow’s video games may be the first efforts at interactive cinema—by either a game designer or a filmmaker—that work.

item.title: Tangled Justice
item.description: John J. Lennon A new book examines the complex relationship between forgiveness and justice through the story of Paula Cooper, who was sentenced to death at the age of sixteen.

item.title: ‘Insouciant Pagan Journal’
item.description: Francesca Wade The Little Review, the radical and short-lived magazine helmed by Jane Heap and Margaret Anderson, was a vanguard of modernism in American culture.

item.title: The Import of Exports
item.description: Robert Kuttner Free trade once aligned with America’s economic and security interests, but in recent years experts have suggested pulling back from globalism and rebuilding the domestic economy.

item.title: Centers on the Margins
item.description: R.J.W. Evans The dark history of Buczacz, an ordinary town in western Ukraine, exemplifies the fate of Jews in the vast marginal territories of East-Central Europe.

item.title: Hopping Across the Line
item.description: John Washington InSoldiers and Kings, Jason De León uses the anthropological method of “deep hanging out” to offer a complicated portrait of migrant smugglers.

item.title: Irresistible Iris
item.description: Frances Wilson Iris Murdoch’s readers return to her to understand the relationship between high intelligence, erotic extremism, and moral virtue.

item.title: Rebels Without a Cause
item.description: James Shapiro In Sam Gold’sRomeo + Juliet, the lovers’ headlong rush into marriage is in tension throughout with the surprising regression to childhood that characterizes so much of the production.

item.title: Joy and Apprehension in Syria
item.description: Ursula Lindsey There is widespread relief after Assad’s fall, though no one is more aware than Syrians themselves of the dangers and challenges that await them.

item.title: Evolution in the Dock
item.description: Adam Hochschild In her new book, Brenda Wineapple brings to life one of the most inflamed chapters in the history of America’s culture wars: the Scopes trial of 1925.

item.title: Limitless Space, Endless Motion
item.description: Sarah L. Kaufman When the choreographer Alexei Ratmansky first saw a tape of Balanchine’sApollo, he watched in disbelief. Here was elegance without exaggeration, tension and beauty without stagy excess.

item.title: Far from the Seventies
item.description: Elaine Blair Two memoirs by women remembering their youthful relationships with older men complicate the definition and implications of “consent.”

item.title: A Deadly Apathy
item.description: David Shulman A blank indifference to cruelty and atrocity as a normative mode of waging war has infected Israel’s collective conscience.

item.title: Player Piano
item.description: Susan Barba a poem

item.title: Baldwin’s Spell
item.description: Darryl Pinckney In James Baldwin’s writing and public appearances, the social and personal, the spoken and written dissolve into one.

item.title: Chaos and Treasure
item.description: Leo Rubinfien No artist has tried harder to get photographs and text to bring each other urgently to life than Jim Goldberg.

item.title: The Kitchen
item.description: Pearl Kan a poem

item.title: Passion’s Countervoices
item.description: Peter Brooks Balzac’sThe Lily in the Valleygives full-throated voice to romantic passion and at the same time contains it, inflating its rhetoric while ironizing it.

item.title: ‘Never Too Much’
item.description: Trevor Jackson If globalization has allowed elites to remove themselves from democratic accountability and regulation, is there any path toward a just economy?

item.title: Dispirited Away
item.description: Caroline Fraser The rise and fall of an evangelical church, founded with progressive intentions and undone by dissension and bad faith

item.title: Unsinkable Paris
item.description: Rachel Donadio The spirit of celebration on the streets of Paris during the Olympics was all the more meaningful to those of us who had lived through so many of the city’s darker recent chapters.

item.title: String Theory
item.description: Susan Tallman Two exhibitions focused on weaving go beyond the functional, the folkloric, and the feminine, tracking fiber’s escape from the connotations of the grid.

item.title: National Vaccine Injury Compensation Program
item.description: Ben Lerner a poem

item.title: Vitruvius & the Warlords
item.description: Ingrid D. Rowland Vitruvius’sTen Books on Architecturewas not only a manual of the building arts but a treatise on how to extend and consolidate the Roman Empire, and lent itself all too well to the autocratic ambitions of Renaissance princes.

item.title: Measles Gone Wild
item.description: Jerome Groopman During a burgeoning measles outbreak, HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has continued to make contradictory remarks, publicly endorsing the measles vaccine while raising doubts about its safety.

item.title: The Frick Reinvigorated
item.description: Martin Filler In an ambitious and long-overdue renovation, the architect Annabelle Selldorf attempted to harmonize with the Frick’s Classical aesthetic while asserting her Modernist credentials.

item.title: Internalizing the Crises
item.description: Julian Bell Joseph Leo Koerner’s latest book considers what art becomes when politics has been stripped down to relations of force.

item.title: A More Perfect Truth
item.description: Lisa Halliday Claire Messud’s exhilarating new novel spans four generations of a French Algerian family reckoning with their place as failed colonists.

item.title: Ambition, Discipline, Nerve
item.description: Heather O’Donnell The qualities that enabled Belle da Costa Greene to cross the color line were the same ones that made her a formidable negotiator and collector for J. P. Morgan’s library, which she led for over twenty years.

item.title: Eddying Toward Doom
item.description: Geoffrey O’Brien Any adaptation ofMoby-Dickmust pick and choose from the novel’s many themes and tones; Jake Heggie’s opera tends toward a frequency attuned to sorrow.

item.title: ‘Why Not All These Things at Once?’
item.description: David Salle The sculptor Arlene Shechet’s work is held together by a combination of stand-up shtick, fairy tales, strong nerves, and high modernist sobriety.

enclosure.url: https://the-ted.github.io/podcast/mp3/‘Why Not All These Things at Once?’.mp3

item.title: The Last Bulwark
item.description: Noah Feldman The fate of our democracy today depends on the judiciary’s commitments to liberty, constitutionalism, and legality.

item.title: Art to Sit On
item.description: Jarrett Earnest For the past forty years people have enjoyed chairs, tables, and benches in public places across North America without realizing they are part of Scott Burton’s radical artistic vision.

item.title: Killing Memories
item.description: Madeleine Thien The Chinese writer Fang Fang’s novelSoft Burialprobes traumatic national memories across several generations, even as her Covid diary in 2020 made her the target of a relentless disinformation campaign in China.

item.title: ‘On the Brink of Erasure’
item.description: Sam Needleman Tacita Dean’s mesmerizing, elegiac drawing and filmmaking spring from both broad exploration and acute focus.

item.title: Writing Like a Mountain
item.description: Nathaniel Rich In the novels of the Swiss writer Charles Ferdinand Ramuz, people become ants and mountains become menacing gods.

item.title: Dead Calm
item.description: Carmen Boullosa, translated from the Spanish bySamantha Schnee a poem

item.title: The Portraitist
item.description: Coco Fusco By using unlikely objects to represent people he had loved and lost, Felix Gonzalez-Torres created the most unforgettable artistic expressions of mourning to emerge from the AIDS crisis.

item.title: Justice for Chagos?
item.description: Atossa Araxia Abrahamian Decades after the Indian Ocean island colony’s inhabitants were forcibly deported to accommodate an American military base, the ICJ has ruled that they be allowed to return. But is international law sufficient to bring them justice?

item.title: A Century of Surrealism
item.description: Jed Perl One hundred years after André Breton launched the Surrealist movement, we’re still trying to make sense of its aims and effects.

item.title: String Theory
item.description: Susan Tallman Two exhibitions focused on weaving go beyond the functional, the folkloric, and the feminine, tracking fiber’s escape from the connotations of the grid.

item.title: String Theory
item.description: Susan Tallman Two exhibitions focused on weaving go beyond the functional, the folkloric, and the feminine, tracking fiber’s escape from the connotations of the grid.

item.title: A Century of Surrealism
item.description: Jed Perl One hundred years after André Breton launched the Surrealist movement, we’re still trying to make sense of its aims and effects.
